section.title: 1. The FlyMine Query Builder: building complex queries

listitem.para: FlyMine allows you to construct complex queries across multiple integrated data sources using a web interface
Building a query using the FlyMine query builder involves the following steps, which are described in more detail below.

To start a new FlyMine query, choose the starting point for your query either from the classes displayed (which have been divided into biologically meaniful categories) or by selecting the 'List all classes' link.
Selecting the class with which to start your query will take you to the main query builder page.
In the model browser, browse to the classes and fields you are interested in.
Select the classes and/or fields you wish to constrain using the -> constrain arrows. Specify your constraints in the right hand constraints list.
Select the classes and/or fields you wish to show in the results output using the "show" buttons. The classes/fields selected will appear in the output fields list.
Press 'show results' to view your results in the results page.
For a walk-through a simple query see the tutorials.
The FlyMine query builder consists of 3 main sections:
A. The class chooser
B. The main query builder page
C. The results display
The screen shot below shows the class chooser. This displays only the main starting points for a query and these have been divided into biologically meaniful categories.

In addition to the above classes a full list of classes from which you can start your query can be accessed by clicking on the 'List all classes' link (see above screenshot). This takes you to the class chooser page (see screenshot below). This page contains a list of classes for which objects exist in the database (i.e. classes for which there is data associated)
Selecting the class from which you wish to start your query and pressing the 'Select' button will take you to the FlyMine query builder page.

The browse model button (accessed from the initial class selection point)allows you to browse the complete FlyMine object model. This shows all the classes in FlyMine, some of which do not yet have data associated with them.
In browse mode, the number on the right shows the number of objects associated with that class.
Clicking on a class name within the browser will take you to the FlyMine query builder page.

section.title: B. The main query builder page

listitem.para: The main FlyMine query builder page is composed of 3 sections (shown in the screen shot below):
a model browser (left)
a constraints list (right)
an output fields list (bottom)
The model browser

The model browser allows you to select the classes that contain the objects you require. Depending on the starting class you will be able to navigate to other classes as defined by the references between the classes (see Classes, objects and fields for an explanation of these concepts). In other words, to combine classes containing the objects you require, you find a path through the classes that link together the information you require. Within the model browser classes that can be accessed from a parent class (ie are linked to the parent class through a reference) are shown as fields within that class.

For each class and field within the model browser there is a 'show' and a 'constrain' (->) option. These are used to either select a field to show in the results output or to constrain in the constraints list.
See The model browser for more information about classes and fields.
The constraints list
The constraints list is on the right hand side of the query builder page. In this section you specify the constraints you wish to apply to particular classes and fields.

To apply a constraint to a field, navigate to the field in the model browser and click on the -> (constrain) next to it. This will add the field to the constraints list and bring up a box in which you specify your constraint.
The type of constraint you can add will vary depending on the type of field you selected to constrain.
The output fields list
The output fields list is located at the bottom of the query builder (underneath the Model browser). Initially the output fields list will say 'No fields selected for output'.
The output fields list shows all fields or classes that you have selected to show in the results output. To select a field to show in the results output you press 'show' next to the field or class.
The order of fields and classes in the output fields list can be changed using the < and > arrows. Fields can be deleted from the output fields list using the x.
The results page displays the first 10 objects returned by your query.
The number of objects displayed can be changed by changing the number in the Page size box and pressing Change.
You can scroll though the objects using Next, or go to the last 10 objects using Last.

The total number of objects returned by your query is estimated. An estimate is given because, for large queries, only a subset of the total number of objects is initially returned by the query. This is to improve query run time for large queries.
From the results page you can save your data to a bag (see Saving bags of data) and export your data in various formats (see Exporting data).
If there are any objects in your results (rather than fields) you can click on an object to view it in detail.

section.title: D. Attribute List vs Browse Mode: 2 modes of result display

listitem.para: There are two modes of result display in FlyMine depending on whether you select attributes of classes to show or an entire Class. This is illustrated in the screenshot below. It is also possible to show a mix of attributes and objects in the result display.

Selecting attributes results in a table-style results output as shown in the results displayed in the screenshot above. Selecting a class to 'show' in the results output means that each object required from that class will be returned. For each object in the database there is a detailed results view which shows all the attributes of the objects and the classes referenced by that object. From this detailed results view it is possible to browse the information contained in the referenced classes.
